sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Deletion of Volume Shadow Copies via WMI with PowerShell - PS Script
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects deletion of Windows Volume Shadow Copies with PowerShell code and Get-WMIObject. This technique is used by numerous ransomware families such as Sodinokibi/REvil

match_context.values: @{ScriptBlockText=Get-WmiObject Win32_Shadowcopy | Remove-WmiObject; MessageTotal=1; ScriptBlockId=6a444d3f-ff6e-4a0f-8e93-f8f6774f81b4; Path=; EventID=4104; MessageNumber=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Deletion of Volume Shadow Copies via WMI with PowerShell
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects deletion of Windows Volume Shadow Copies with PowerShell code and Get-WMIObject. This technique is used by numerous ransomware families such as Sodinokibi/REvil

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Hashes=SHA1=1B3B40FBC889FD4C645CC12C85D0805AC36BA254,MD5=95000560239032BC68B4C2FDFCDEF913,SHA256=D3F8FADE829D2B7BD596C4504A6DAE5C034E789B6A3DEFBE013BDA7D14466677,IMPHASH=741776AACCFC5B71FF59832DCDCACE0F; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\wbem\wmiprvse.exe; CommandLine=powershell.exe -Command "Get-WmiObject Win32_Shadowcopy | Remove-WmiObject"; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\wbem\WmiPrvSE.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Uncommon File Created In Office Startup Folder
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of a file with an uncommon extension in an Office application startup folder

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Hashes=SHA1=1B3B40FBC889FD4C645CC12C85D0805AC36BA254,MD5=95000560239032BC68B4C2FDFCDEF913,SHA256=D3F8FADE829D2B7BD596C4504A6DAE5C034E789B6A3DEFBE013BDA7D14466677,IMPHASH=741776AACCFC5B71FF59832DCDCACE0F; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\wbem\wmiprvse.exe; CommandLine=powershell.exe -Command "Get-WmiObject Win32_Shadowcopy | Remove-WmiObject"; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\wbem\WmiPrvSE.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential WMI Lateral Movement WmiPrvSE Spawned PowerShell
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects Powershell as a child of the WmiPrvSE process. Which could be a sign of lateral movement via WMI.

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=1B3B40FBC889FD4C645CC12C85D0805AC36BA254,MD5=95000560239032BC68B4C2FDFCDEF913,SHA256=D3F8FADE829D2B7BD596C4504A6DAE5C034E789B6A3DEFBE013BDA7D14466677,IMPHASH=741776AACCFC5B71FF59832DCDCACE0F; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\wbem\wmiprvse.exe; CommandLine=powershell.exe -Command "Get-WmiObject Win32_Shadowcopy | Remove-WmiObject"; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\wbem\WmiPrvSE.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Credential Manager Access By Uncommon Applications
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects suspicious processes based on name and location that access the windows credential manager and vault.
Which can be a sign of credential stealing. Example case would be usage of mimikatz "dpapi::cred" function

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: PowerShell Module File Created By Non-PowerShell Process
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of a new PowerShell module ".psm1", ".psd1", ".dll", ".ps1", etc. by a non-PowerShell process
Detects unusual processes accessing desktop.ini, which can be leveraged to alter how Explorer displays a folder's content (i.e. renaming files) without changing them on disk.
Detects the creation of the "PSScriptPolicyTest" PowerShell script by an uncommon process. This file is usually generated by Microsoft Powershell to test against Applocker.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Files With System Process Name In Unsuspected Locations
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects the creation of an executable with a system process name in folders other than the system ones (System32, SysWOW64, etc.).
It is highly recommended to perform an initial baseline before using this rule in production.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Sander Wiebing, Tim Shelton, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Access To Windows DPAPI Master Keys By Uncommon Applications
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects file access requests to the the Windows Data Protection API Master keys by an uncommon application.
This can be a sign of credential stealing. Example case would be usage of mimikatz "dpapi::masterkey" function
Detects non-interactive PowerShell activity by looking at the "powershell" process with a non-user GUI process such as "explorer.exe" as a parent.

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=1B3B40FBC889FD4C645CC12C85D0805AC36BA254,MD5=95000560239032BC68B4C2FDFCDEF913,SHA256=D3F8FADE829D2B7BD596C4504A6DAE5C034E789B6A3DEFBE013BDA7D14466677,IMPHASH=741776AACCFC5B71FF59832DCDCACE0F; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\wbem\wmiprvse.exe; CommandLine=powershell.exe -Command "Get-WmiObject Win32_Shadowcopy | Remove-WmiObject"; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\wbem\WmiPrvSE.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Load Of RstrtMgr.DLL By An Uncommon Process
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects the load of RstrtMgr DLL (Restart Manager) by an uncommon process.
This library has been used during ransomware campaigns to kill processes that would prevent file encryption by locking them (e.g. Conti ransomware, Cactus ransomware). It has also recently been seen used by the BiBi wiper for Windows.
It could also be used for anti-analysis purposes by shut downing specific processes.

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=E73CC7B108B1509663366C7B6EB3EE9F34C81BC0,MD5=7C2EB91CE1A90EE355DACA061FC12CB3,SHA256=27CED8D6D6F07C09CB1277FE69FC64CF087ABB4EB5B85DCEB7DA1175DCC9E479,IMPHASH=682F7D32AA9331B44703F9533C0C3308; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; SignatureStatus=Valid; ImageLoaded=C:\Windows\System32\RstrtMgr.dll; Description=Restart Manager; OriginalFileName=RstrtMgr.dll; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); EventID=7; Signed=true; Signature=Microsoft Windows; Image=C:\Users\george\AppData\Local\Temp\3582-490\file.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects malware by known bad imphash or rich_pe_header_hash
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Arnim Rupp

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This Yara rule from ISH Tecnologia's Heimdall Security Research Team detects key components of Akira Ransomware
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: 0x0d4y-Icaro Cesar

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered virus. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.
